ygData.msgSnippet: ... It is up to an operator to give descriptive names to arc files. If the arc names are descriptive than this is not a problem. ... When I run repeating

 > It's not possible to tell from file names which job each arc file
 > comes from?

It is up to an operator to give descriptive names to arc files.
If the arc names are descriptive than this is not a problem.

 > During harvesting every job has its own directory but in the end one
 > may place all arcs into a bigger pool for further processing.
 >
 > Would a series number be unique only inside a job so you could have
 > files
 >
 > name - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
 > name - 00001 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
 > name - 00001-  timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
 > name - 00001 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz
 >
 > produced by four different jobs. I somehow think a running series
 > number in an archive implies that no two files in an archive have
 > identical s-numbers (even if their timestamps differ)

When I run repeating crawls I usually name arc files so that is easy to tell which arcs belong to 
which crawl. For example:

name-weekly-00 - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
name-weekly-01 - 00001 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
name-weekly-02 - 00001-  timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
name-weekly-03 - 00001 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz

where xx in name-weekly-xx- represent week number.

 > S-number makes file names more unique but it's not very informative.
 > Would it be possible to use job name instead
 >
 > OperatorGivenName - Jobname - Timestamp - IP.arc.gz for example =>
 >
 > finland - photoarchives - timestamp - IP.arc.gz
 >
 > Slight problem of course that job names have variable lengths unlike
 > s-numbers.

All this can be achieved with using descriptive arc names. For example:

finland-photoarchives00-00000-timestamp-IP.arc.gz
finland-photoarchives00-00001-timestamp-IP.arc.gz
finland-photoarchives01-00000-timestamp-IP.arc.gz
finland-photoarchives01-00001-timestamp-IP.arc.gz

where 'finland-photoarchivesXX-' is a arc name prefix.

Also, I believe that we are going to swap positions of series# and timestamp. This way we can easily 
sort arc files by date which in some cases can help determine which arcs belong to which crawl.
Example where an operator have used same arc prefix for multiple crawls:

CONGRESS-20040124024708-00000.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124024925-00001.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025035-00002.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025146-00003.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025230-00000.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025250-00001.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025353-00002.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025531-00003.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025656-00000.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025750-00001.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124025849-00002.arc.gz
CONGRESS-20040124030003-00003.arc.gz

So simple by sorting arc names and observing increasing series number we can find out which arcs 
belong to which crawl.

i.
